title: Key Milestones in Technological History
content:
# Key Milestones in Technological History

## Industrial Revolution (1760-1840)
- **Steam Engine**: James Watt's improved steam engine (1769) increased efficiency by 75% over previous designs
- **First Factories**: The first water-powered textile factory was established in 1771 in Cromford, England
- **Railways**: First steam locomotive railway (Stockton and Darlington Railway) opened in 1825
- **Economic Impact**: Manufacturing productivity increased 400% in the UK between 1770-1840

## Electric Age (1880s-1930s)
- **Light Bulb**: Edison's carbon filament bulb (1879) lasted 1,200 hours vs. 40 hours for previous designs
- **AC Power**: Nikola Tesla developed the first AC induction motor in 1887
- **Electrification**: By 1925, 50% of American homes had electric power
- **Communications**: First transatlantic radio transmission occurred in 1901 by Guglielmo Marconi

## Digital Revolution (1950s-1980s)
- **First Computers**: ENIAC (1945) weighed 30 tons and performed 5,000 operations per second
- **Microprocessor**: Intel 4004 (1971) contained 2,300 transistors
- **Personal Computing**: IBM PC (1981) featured 4.77MHz processor and 16KB RAM
- **Internet Development**: ARPANET first connected four university computers in 1969

## Internet Era (1990s-2010s)
- **World Wide Web**: Tim Berners-Lee created the WWW in 1991 with 26 websites by end of 1992
- **Google**: Founded in 1998, handled 1 million searches per day by end of 1998
- **Smartphone Revolution**: First iPhone (2007) featured 3.5-inch display, 128MB RAM
- **Social Media Growth**: Facebook reached 1 billion users in October 2012

## AI and Automation Era (2010-Present)
- **Deep Learning Breakthrough**: AlexNet in 2012 reduced image recognition error rates from 26% to 15%
- **Voice Assistants**: By 2023, 90% of smartphones had AI assistants integrated
- **Autonomous Vehicles**: As of 2025, over 50 cities worldwide have autonomous taxi services
- **AI Market Growth**: Global AI market size increased from $62.35 billion in 2020 to $309 billion in 2025
